This IRM section was revised as follows:
Brief Description
Clariﬁed the parties to the mediation may not make a stenographic record, audio or video tape recording, or other transcript of the mediation session.
AUDIENCE
Appeals
Table of Contents
for Collection Cases

) A primary objective of the Internal Revenue Service is to resolve tax sies at the lowest level without sacriﬁcing the quality and integrity of those determinations. Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR), or mediation, achieve this objective. (

) The objective of Fast Track Mediation - Collection (FTMC) is to allow Business/Self-Employed (SB/SE) Collection personnel and taxpayers an tunity to mediate their collection disputes with an Office of Appeals serving as a neutral party. . (
) Appeals and Collection jointly manage and administer the FTMC Program. (

) Appeals officers and settlement officers trained in mediation serve as mediators, in FTMC cases. The Appeals mediator does not have authority and cannot render a decision regarding any issue in dispute. (
) The taxpayer does not have the option of using a non-IRS employee as a mediator. (
) The entire process is estimated to take
calendar days. The case remains in Collection’s jurisdiction during the entire process. (
) Participation in FTMC is optional for both Collection and the taxpayer. (

) FTMC neither suspends nor extends the period of time the taxpayer has request a hearing before Appeals. FTMC is not generally available if a Offer in Compromise (OIC) rejection letter notifying the taxpayer of tive appeal rights, or a Trust Fund Recovery Penalty (TFRP) Letter

, Notiﬁcation of Proposed Trust Fund Recovery Penalty, was issued there is not sufficient time to complete the FTMC process. If the parties do reach an agreement on a mediated issue, FTMC does not eliminate or other available ADR options or the taxpayer’s opportunity to request a before Appeals through the traditional Appeals process. (
) Fast Track Mediation (FTM) was introduced in
and Rev. Proc. which became effective on June
, formally established the FTM program to expedite case resolution and to expand the range of dispute lution options available to SB/SE taxpayers. (
) Rev. Proc.
became effective on November
, obsoleting Proc.

and creating SB/SE Fast Track Mediation -Collection. allows taxpayers an opportunity to resolve certain OIC and TFRP disputes an expedited basis with a mediator from the Office of Appeals serving as neutral party. (
) Rev. Proc.
, effective on November
, serves as the for FTMC. (
) Appeals officers trained in mediation serve as Appeals mediators for issues and cases. The Appeals mediator does not have settlement and cannot render a decision regarding any issue in dispute. (
) Appeals and Collection jointly manage and administer the FTMC program. Internal Revenue Manual

The table below lists common acronyms used in this section:

Term Acronym Alternative Dispute Resolution ADR Appeals Team Manager ATM Fast Track Mediation - Collection FTMC Offer in Compromise OIC Reasonable Collection Potential RCP Trust Fund Recovery Penalty TFRP
The Appeals mediator assists Collection and the taxpayer to understand the nature of the dispute and to reach a mutually satisfactory resolution.
The Appeals mediator uses mediation techniques to focus issues and lead Col- lection and the taxpayer to self-determine the outcome of the dispute.

) The opportunity to mediate should only be granted after the Collection Manager has reviewed the case and determined that the case meets the bility requirements outlined below and the issues in dispute may be resolved mediation. (
) If Collection agrees to participate in FTMC, Collection completes Form Agreement to Mediate, and Collection secures the taxpayer’s (or the autho- rized representative’s) signature on the form. (

, Collection will provide a copy of the completed FTMC request to the taxpayer and follow locally established guidelines for submitting the FTMC request to Appeals for ﬁnal FTMC acceptance. An FTMC request includes following: a. Form

, signed by both parties. b. The taxpayer’s written summary of his or her position with respect to disputed issues. This is not treated as a formal protest, and a formal protest is not required. c. Collection’s written summary of its position with respect to the disputed issues. d. Full RCP computation for an OIC case, which will generally consists of Income/Expense and Asset/Equity Tables (IET and AET), or a full trust fund computation in a TFRP case Note: All documents submitted with the Form
are available to the other party. (

) FTMC may not be the appropriate dispute resolution process for all SB/SE Collection taxpayers. The Collection Group Manager or designee and the in FTMC taxpayer will evaluate their individual circumstances to determine if this process meets their needs. (

) FTMC may apply only when all other collection issues are resolved except the issue(s) requested for the FTMC process. The issue(s) to be mediated must be fully developed with clearly deﬁned positions by both parties. (

) Prior to FTMC, Collection must have: a. Completed a thorough investigation and evaluation of the disputed b. Addressed all arguments raised by the taxpayer, and c. Made a reasonable attempt to resolve the dispute and reach an agreement. (

) FTMC may not be the appropriate dispute resolution process for all SB/SE Collection taxpayers. The Collection Group Manager or designee and the taxpayer will evaluate their individual circumstances to determine if this process meets their needs. (

) FTMC may apply only when all other collection issues are resolved except for the issue(s) requested for the FTMC process. The issue(s) to be mediated must be fully developed with clearly deﬁned positions by both parties. (

) Prior to FTMC, Collection must have: a. Completed a thorough investigation and evaluation of the disputed issue, b. Addressed all arguments raised by the taxpayer, and c. Made a reasonable attempt to resolve the dispute and reach an agreement.

Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR) Program
) See also Publication
, Fast Track Mediation - A Process for Prompt lution of Tax Issues. (

) FTMC is generally appropriate for legal and factual issues regarding certain OIC and TFRP cases and issues. FTMC is not the place to consider a new in FTMC issue or to develop an undeveloped or underdeveloped issue. (

) Provided all relevant facts are known by both parties, OIC cases or issues would generally be appropriate for FTMC include: a. The value of a taxpayer’s assets, including those held by a third party b. The value of dissipated assets and what amount should be included in overall determination of reasonable collection potential c. Whether the taxpayer meets the criteria for deviating from national local expense standards d. A taxpayer’s proportionate interest in jointly held assets e. Projections of future income based on calculations other than current income f. The calculation of a taxpayer’s future ability to pay when living are shared with a non-liable person g. Doubt as to Liability cases worked by Collection h. Other factual determinations, such as whether a taxpayer’s contributions into a retirement savings account are discretionary or mandatory as a condition of employment (
) Both pre-assessment (Letter

) and post-assessment (claim) TFRP are eligible for FTMC. Provided all relevant facts are known by both parties, TFRP issues that would generally be appropriate for FTMC include: a. Whether a person was required to collect, truthfully account for, and pay over income, employment or excise taxes b. Whether a responsible person willfully failed to collect, truthfully account for, and pay over such tax, or willfully attempted in any manner to evade or defeat payment of such tax c. Whether a taxpayer properly designated a payment to the trust fund portion of the unpaid tax d. Whether the taxpayer provided sufficient corporate payroll records to establish that a corporate tax deposit was in the amount required by Treas. Reg. §
(c) and thus was considered a designated payment to be applied to both the trust fund and non-trust fund portions the employment taxes associated with that speciﬁc payroll. See the to IRM
), Calculating the TFRP. (

) Not all cases worked by Collection are eligible for FTMC. The following cases are excluded from FTMC: Issues a. Assessment of the hazards of litigation, which would require the from FTMC - mediator to hold settlement authority b. Cases referred to the Department of Justice c. Cases worked at an SB/SE Campus site d. Collection Appeals Program (CAP) cases e. Collection Due Process (CDP) cases f. Frivolous issues, such as, but not limited to, those identiﬁed in Rev.

Track Mediation for Collection Cases 8.26.3
Collection cases in which the taxpayer has failed to respond to IRS com- munications or failed to submit documentation to Collection for consideration Certain OIC cases; see IRM
Issues for which mediation would be inconsistent with sound tax adminis- tration Issues that have otherwise been identiﬁed in subsequent published guidance issued by the IRS as excluded from FTMC
A taxpayer owes $
and is offering $
to settle the tax During negotiations with Collection, the offer specialist determined rea- sonable collection potential (RCP) was $
, part of which was a determination that the taxpayer had net realizable equity in her residence of $
based upon a Fair Market Value of $
(yielding a Quick Sale Value of $
) with a prior secured interest of $
The only issue for which the taxpayer seeks mediation is her belief that the residence has a Fair Market Value of $
(yielding a Quick Sale Value of $
and thus net realiz- able equity of $

for RCP purposes). The taxpayer and Collection agree on all other aspects of the RCP calculation. Even though the value of the taxpayer’s residence is an issue over which IRS would generally agree to mediate, it would not be consistent with sound tax administration to do so in this instance because even if Collection fully conceded its position on the value of the residence, it would not impact the overall determination that RCP exceeds the taxpayer’s liability.

value of the taxpayer’s residence is an issue over which IRS would generally agree to mediate, it would not be consistent with sound tax administration to do so in this instance because even if Collection fully conceded its position on the value of the residence, it would not impact the overall determination that RCP exceeds the taxpayer’s liability.

a. Cases in which the taxpayer has the ability to pay in full based on the un- adjusted ﬁnancial information submitted by the taxpayer, except where economic hardship conditions apply and the Collection Group Manager is delegated authority to approve OIC acceptance under Delegation Order
, To Accept, Reject, Return, Terminate or Acknowledge Withdrawals of Offers in Compromise. See IRM
, Delegation Order

b. Cases in which the taxpayer declines to amend or increase the offer despite having no speciﬁc disagreement with the valuations, ﬁgures, or methodology used by Collection in determining RCP c. Cases in which the disputed issue is explicitly addressed in established guidance
A taxpayer submitted a FTMC request listing a disallowed monthly payment towards a $

unsecured consumer elec- tronics retailer debt. The taxpayer and Collection agree on all other aspects of the RCP calculation. Payment toward an unsecured debt of this nature is not considered a necessary living expense per IRM
, Financial Analysis Handbook, and IRM
, Offer in Compromise, Financial Analysis. The instructions in Form
-B, Form

Booklet, Offer in mise, also state unsecured debt payments are not generally allowed. Because the issue for which the taxpayer seeks mediation is explicitly addressed in established guidance, FTMC is not available in this instance.
Cases in which Delegation Order 5-1 requires a level of approval higher than that of the Collection Group Manager
Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR) Program
In addition to the general exclusions listed in Rev. Proc. 2016-57, the following TFRP cases or issues are also excluded from FTMC:
An issue designated for litigation or docketed in any court Issues for which mediation would not be consistent with sound tax admin
istration, e.g., those in which Collection has no ability to settle, such as arguments based upon something other than responsibility, willfulness or the TFRP amount. Examples include:

the TFRP amount. Examples include: Example: Officer A requested FTMC in a proposed TFRP assessment case. During the investigation process, Officer A raised no speciﬁc responsibility or willfulness arguments and did not dispute the amount of the proposed TFRP assessment. Officer A’s only argument is that Officer B, who did not contest his liability for the TFRP, is more responsible and therefore IRS should go after Officer B instead. Liability for the TFRP under IRC

is based strictly on the merits of each individual’s responsibility and willfulness. If Officer A meets the statutory responsibility and willfulness requirements and raises no arguments to dispute such during his appeal, then simply saying someone else is more responsible is not an issue that Collection has an ability to settle and FTMC is not available. Example: Officer C requested FTMC in a TFRP claim case arguing that she was not directly involved in making federal tax deposits. The case ﬁle, however, shows she was an officer and a share- holder, signed

% of all checks and almost all of the payroll checks, exercised her authority to determine which creditors would be paid, hired and ﬁred employees, and was fully aware of the unpaid taxes as they accrued. In this instance, determined that even if it conceded that she wasn’t directly involved in making federal tax deposits, the issues of responsi- bility and willfulness were still sufficiently established. Even though IRS would generally agree to mediate speciﬁc aspects of responsibility, FTMC would not be consistent with sound tax administration to do so in this instance because the disputed issue doesn’t have a sufficient impact on the overall determina- tion of liability under IRC

Officer A requested FTMC in a proposed TFRP assessment case. During the investigation process, Officer A raised no speciﬁc responsibility or willfulness arguments and did not dispute the amount of the proposed TFRP assessment. A’s only argument is that Officer B, who did not contest his liability for the TFRP, is more responsible and therefore IRS should go after Officer B instead. Liability for the TFRP under IRC

is based strictly on the merits of each individual’s responsibility and willfulness. If Officer A meets the statutory responsibility and willfulness requirements and raises no arguments to dispute such during his appeal, then simply saying someone else is more responsible is not an issue that Collection has an ability to settle and FTMC is not available.
Officer C requested FTMC in a TFRP claim case arguing that she was not directly involved in making federal tax deposits. The case ﬁle, however, shows she was an officer and a share- holder, signed

% of all checks and almost all of the payroll checks, exercised her authority to determine which creditors would be paid, hired and ﬁred employees, and was fully aware of the unpaid taxes as they accrued. In this instance, Collection determined that even if it conceded that she wasn’t directly involved in making federal tax deposits, the issues of responsi- bility and willfulness were still sufficiently established. Even though IRS would generally agree to mediate speciﬁc aspects of responsibility, FTMC would not be consistent with sound tax administration to do so in this instance because the disputed issue doesn’t have a sufficient impact on the overall determina-
Cases where the taxpayer did not act in good faith during the TFRP inves- tigation process. Examples include:

Example Description Eligible for FTMC? 1 Taxpayer did not participate in the TFRP investigation process by No failing to show up for scheduled meetings. Example: Revenue officer Pike sent out a letter scheduling a TFRP interview for March 30. The taxpayer did not show up on March 30 and did not contact Pike to postpone or reschedule the meeting.
Fast Track Mediation for Collection Cases
) The FTMC process is conﬁdential with respect to all parties pursuant to IRC

Employees of the IRS, and persons invited by the IRS to participate in the FTMC process, must adhere to the conﬁdentiality and disclosure of the Internal Revenue Code. The mediation process and any information relating to the mediation is conﬁdential and may not be used or disclosed by any party, mediator, participant or observer (including any person under contract to the IRS pursuant to IRC
(n)) , except as provided by statute, such as IRC
, and
U.S.C. section
) Collection and Appeals management work out local procedures to meet time frames and foster effective communication between the functions. (
) Upon receipt of the FTMC request, the Appeals Team Manager (ATM) the case for completeness and eligibility. (
) All applications to the FTMC process require the approval of an ATM before acceptance into FTMC.
) The FTMC process is conﬁdential with respect to all parties pursuant to IRC

Employees of the IRS, and persons invited by the IRS to participate in the FTMC process, must adhere to the conﬁdentiality and disclosure provisions of the Internal Revenue Code. The mediation process and any information relating to the mediation is conﬁdential and may not be used or disclosed by any party, mediator, participant or observer (including any person under contract to the IRS pursuant to IRC
(n)) , except as provided by statute, such as IRC
, and
U.S.C. section
All applications to the FTMC process require the approval of an ATM before acceptance into FTMC.
Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR) (
) The ATM may also contact the Appeals Policy FTMC program analyst to discuss mediation eligibility and other mediation-related issues. (
) If the FTMC request is accepted, the ATM will: a. Date the Form
b. Provide a copy of the dated Form

to the Appeals Account and cessing Support (APS) c. Notify the Collection Group Manager d. Select an appeals officer (AO) or settlement officer (SO) to serve as FTMC Appeals mediator e. Assign the case within two (
) business days of receipt of the Form
) The Appeals mediator must be trained in mediation. A full list of trained mediators is available on the Appeals website. The taxpayer does not option of using a non-IRS mediator in an FTMC case. (
) The Appeals mediator does not have settlement authority and cannot decision regarding any disputed issue. (
) In preparation for the FTMC session, thoroughly review Revenue
and IRM
) If Appeals determines the case does not qualify or is otherwise not for FTMC, the ATM will: Denied a. Notify the taxpayer within two (
) business days of receipt of the Form
b. Notify the Collection Group Manager c. Return all paperwork to Collection (
) The decision to not accept an application for the FTMC program is ﬁnal not subject to administrative appeal or judicial review. See case eligibility guidelines above. (

) Due to the inherent conﬂict that results because the Appeals mediator is employee of the IRS, the Appeals mediator provides a statement to the FTMC taxpayer stating the following: a. conﬁrmation of his/her proposed service as a mediator, b. he/she is a current employee of the IRS, c. a conﬂict results from his/her continued status as an IRS employee, d. this conﬂict will not interfere in the mediator’s ability to impartially the case. (
) The Appeals mediator schedules the mediation session with the taxpayer Collection within
business days after case assignment. The Appeals mediator shares participant information with both parties and has the to limit the number of participants. (

) Standard mediation techniques and procedures are applied in the session. Generally, the mediation session begins with an initial joint with all parties present. Both the taxpayer and Collection are given ample portunity to present their positions. After the initial joint discussion, the mediator may hold separate sessions with the parties. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
C
Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR) Program
The ATM may also contact the Appeals Policy FTMC program analyst to discuss mediation eligibility and other mediation-related issues.
(09-27-2017) Conducting an FTMC Session
for Collection Cases
) At any time, either party may withdraw from the process prior to reaching a resolution by notifying the other party and the mediator in writing. (
) The entire process normally takes an average of

calendar days to complete, but if requested by either party, the Appeals mediator can allow reasonable delay. Any delays are communicated to and coordinated with parties. If the mediation session cannot be held within a reasonable time, the Appeals mediator may consider returning the FTMC request to lection and advise both parties. Before returning the request the Appeals mediator should discuss the case with management. (

) The mediator may recommend to the parties a possible resolution of one more of the issues considered in FTMC based on the mediator’s analysis the issues. Any recommendation made by the mediator does not bind the parties and is not a decision regarding any issue in dispute. See Rev.
, section
) The Appeals mediator has the right to ask either party for additional tion in order to have a full understanding of the issues being mediated. (
) The parties to the mediation may not make a stenographic record, audio or video tape recording, or other transcript of the mediation session. See Rev. Proc
, section

) If during the mediation session, the taxpayer and/or Collection present(s) information or new issues not previously considered, the mediator may consider postponing or terminating the session until both parties have adequate time to review and evaluate the information. (

) If meaningful progress toward resolution stops, the Appeals mediator may terminate the process by notifying the taxpayer and Collection in writing. Appeals mediator may also postpone or terminate the session if: a. The taxpayer or Collection presents new information or new issues the mediation session, b. The taxpayer wishes to submit a substantial amount of additional mentary information, c. The taxpayer wishes to present new witnesses, including experts, or d. For other good cause. Note: Any issue that is the subject of a terminated mediation session treated as mediated for purposes of determining PAM eligibility. Rev. Proc.
, section

) If the Appeals mediator postpones a mediation session, the Appeals will communicate and coordinate his or her decision with both parties. A decision by the Appeals mediator that postponement is necessary may in a longer period for completion of the FTMC process. (
) If the mediation session is terminated, Collection will close the unagreed through established OIC or TFRP closing procedures.

a. The taxpayer or Collection presents new information or new issues the mediation session, b. The taxpayer wishes to submit a substantial amount of additional docu
mentary information, c. The taxpayer wishes to present new witnesses, including experts, or d. For other good cause.

) If the Appeals mediator postpones a mediation session, the Appeals mediator will communicate and coordinate his or her decision with both parties. A decision by the Appeals mediator that postponement is necessary may result in a longer period for completion of the FTMC process.
Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR) (
) A resolution reached by the parties through mediation is not binding on the parties for taxable years not covered by the agreement. Closing (
) If the case is resolved at the mediation session, the Appeals mediator will the parties to sign the Form
, Fast Track Mediator’s Report. A copy of the report is provided to the taxpayer and Collection. (
) The Mediator submits the original Form
to his/her ATM along with a copy of the Case Activity Record (CAR). The manager initials and dates the report then submits to APS for closing. (
) Once SB/SE secures the appropriate closing documents from the taxpayer, case is closed through Collection’s established OIC or TFRP closing proce- dures. (
) APS uses the general provisions for closing cases found in IRM
, Account and Processing Support (APS), Closing Procedures. Closing (
) The Appeals mediator will close the FTMC work unit using one of the for Appeals Closing Codes: •
- Case fully resolved •
- Case not resolved •
- Case partially resolved •
- Withdrawals (
) The prohibition against ex parte communications between Appeals and IRS employees provided by section
(a) of the Internal Revenue Parte in FTMC Cases Restructuring and Reform Act of

does not apply to the arising in the FTMC program because Appeals personnel, in facilitating an agreement between the taxpayer and Collection, are not acting in their tional Appeals settlement role. (
) See section
of Rev. Proc.
, Ex Parte Communications Appeals and Other Internal Revenue Service Employees, Alternative Resolution, for additional information. (

) At the conclusion of the mediation session, the Appeals mediator will the taxpayer with the IRS Appeals Fast Track Mediation - Collection Satisfaction Customer Satisfaction Survey, along with a return envelope. The Appeals mediator should explain the need for the survey and encourage the complete and return it to Appeals. This survey is used to evaluate the and capture feedback. (

) The Appeals mediator should also: • Inform the taxpayer participation in the survey is voluntary • Provide the taxpayer with a pre-addressed envelope with the return address of the Appeals Policy FTMC program analyst • Request that the taxpayer return the survey within one week
